--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
<snip>
> Hey Mitchell, this is a very nice result.  It does
> make you wonder why
> it needs 40 neurons?  (I assume you mean 40 hidden
> neurons.)
> What is going on that such a small amount of
> information is being
> encoded by so many variables?  I also wonder about
> the theoretical
> aspects...what is the theoretical minimum # of
> neurons needed?

I think there is more going on than is immediately
apparent.  There are 8 input lines.  The ANN "sees"
three sets of these before it makes its first move,
although the first set is always the same,
representing face down.  The second set is really not
important.  Perfect play could be based just on the
last set of 8 lines.  (so maybe you are right.)
The ANN, remembering what it "saw", must then pick one
of four cards by settinng one output line.  To play
perfectly it must use what it remembers.  Then, based
of this result, and again using its memory, it must
pick the remaining correct card.

BTW, the hidden neuron classification does not really
apply here, or must be carefully defined.  All neurons
receive all inputs.  All neurons also receive inputs
from all the other neurons, and from themselves. 
However, only the first four neurons are output
neurons, so you could say that there are 36 hidden
neurons.  In this case the only difference between
hidden or not hiddent is that the non-hidden neurons'
output is used.

BTW, I allow the net to settle while holding the input
values.  I let it take up to 16 updates for the
outputs to reach a state where only 1 line is high. 
Of course it may not really have settled, just because
1 line out of only 4 outputs is high, but that's the
way the current code is.  Maybe that's a serious
defect, and I should require all the outputs to
stabilize.

> You may want to try ablating neurons, or cutting
> them out of the
> network one by one, and seeing if it still performs
> alright.  It may
> turn out some of them don't matter.  Note that you
> can ablate a neuron
> either by literally removing it, or by turning it's
> output into random
> noise.  I've heard arguments for doing it both ways.
> 
> It also makes you wonder how NEAT would do, since it

I will do that.  I think that neat could evolve a
perfect player of this 4-card game, although I'm not
certain.  We can't be certain until someone sets it up
and does it.
